paper_title: Deformation behavior and strengthening effects of an eutectic AlCoCrFeNi2.1 high entropy alloy probed by in-situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction and post-mortem EBSD

graphs.title: Tensile strain-stress curves and strain hardening behavior (as-cast AlCoCrFeNi2.1)
graphs.description: Figure 5 shows macroscopic tensile response of the eutectic HEA, including engineering and true stress–strain curves, and the strain-hardening rate.
graphs.about_graph: Room-temperature uniaxial tension of the as-cast eutectic AlCoCrFeNi2.1 alloy. The plot contains (i) engineering stress–strain, (ii) true stress–strain, and (iii) strain hardening rate.
graphs.x_axis_label: Strain (%) — engineering for the black curve; true for the red curve
graphs.y_axis_label: Stress (MPa) — left axis; Strain hardening rate (MPa) — right axis for blue curve

curves.curve_description: Macroscopic engineering stress vs. strain (black diamonds).
curves.about_curve: Represents nominal response; used to report yield and tensile strength.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Uses engineering definitions; lower values at large strain compared to true curve.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Derived from the same tensile test of the same alloy and specimen geometry.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.077.

curves.curve_description: Macroscopic true stress vs. true strain (red squares).
curves.about_curve: Accounts for instantaneous cross‑section changes; shows higher stress at given strain.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Uses true definitions; generally above engineering curve at plastic strains.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, same test; both reflect bulk response.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.078.

graphs.title: Phase stress partitioning during in‑situ synchrotron tensile loading
graphs.description: Partitioned phase stresses for FCC and B2 BCC phases compared to macroscopic and rule‑of‑mixtures responses.
graphs.about_graph: Using in‑situ high‑energy XRD, stresses carried by disordered FCC and ordered B2 BCC phases were computed; the macroscopic curve and ROM combination are also shown.

curves.curve_description: Partitioned stress borne by the disordered FCC phase (blue).
curves.about_curve: Softer phase; yields first (~320–350 MPa) and exhibits minimal hardening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower modulus/yield; smaller stress increase after yielding than B2 BCC.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Calculated from the same in‑situ diffraction dataset for the same alloy.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.080.

curves.curve_description: Partitioned stress borne by the ordered B2 BCC phase (red).
curves.about_curve: Harder phase; yields later (~900 MPa partitioned stress) and hardens strongly.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Much larger stress increase with strain; primary contributor to macroscopic hardening.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same test and analysis method; stresses referenced to macroscopic strain.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.079.

curves.curve_description: Weighted combination of FCC and B2 BCC stresses by phase volume fraction (green).
curves.about_curve: Demonstrates that partitioned stresses reproduce the macroscopic response when mixed by volume fraction.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Model curve; not a directly measured stress in a single phase.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Built from the same phase stresses and phase fractions of the alloy.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.077.

curves.about_curve: Direct tensile response of the bulk material for comparison with ROM.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Not phase‑resolved; measured from the load cell and extensometer.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same specimen/experiment as the partitioned curves.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.076.

graphs.title: Effect of FCC/B2 BCC volume fraction on calculated mechanical response
graphs.description: Model curves demonstrating how changing phase volume fractions changes the stress–strain response.
graphs.about_graph: Rule‑of‑mixtures based calculation using phase stresses, showing higher strength with increasing B2 BCC content and higher ductility with more FCC.

curves.about_curve: Dominance of strengthening B2 BCC phase maximizes flow stress.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same ROM framework; same phase stress inputs.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.080.

curves.about_curve: Reduced B2 BCC fraction lowers strength relative to 90/10 curve.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.079.

curves.about_curve: Equal phase fractions yield mid‑range stresses.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same ROM method with varied phase fractions only.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.076.

curves.about_curve: Soft FCC phase dominates mechanical response.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Second lowest strength in the set.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Computed from identical phase stress inputs.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.080.

curves.about_curve: High FCC fraction minimizes flow stress while favoring deformability.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: ROM with same phase stresses; only volume fractions differ.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.079.
